Description: Rim and neck sherd of Attic red- or black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black with added red band below rim; painted decoration on top of rim consisting of confronting lion and boar in silhouette style with pair of slanting lines in dilute brown at right probably indicating start of handle panel; on edge of rim, debased ivy; underside of overhang and upper most part of neck reserved; exterior of neck glazed streaky black. Drill hole for analysis.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.1165. The fabric was analysed by M. Hughes and found to be Attic: Harbottle, G., Hughes, M. J. and Seleem, S. 'The origin of black-figure Greek ceramics found in Naucratis (Nile Delta)', Archaeometry 47, 2005, 511-8. For parallels, see the column krater fragment Athens P 25273 in Agora XIII, pl. 46, no. 476, 161 (comments). Venit puts this sherd with British Museum 1886,0401.1165, taking both as red figure vases dating about 500-490 BC and suggests that both are by the same hand, and possibly from the same vase as Heidelberg I.65 (CVA Heidelberg 4, pl. 166, no. 1-2, and fig. 28).
Brussels A.1810, dedicated to Aphrodite, is perhaps from the same vase.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 486-7, no. C8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0167) (Phase 1)
